conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the suitcase and use the given information to find the angle θ and the coefficient of friction μ.
The image shows a suitcase which can be either pushed or pulled on the ground.
The total mass of the suitcase is 15 kg, and the gravitational acceleration is g = 10 m/s².
The resistance of the suitcase to the ground is proportional to the supporting force of the ground, with the ratio being μ.
The minimum value of the pull is 90 N, and the angle between the pull and the horizontal direction is θ.
The suitcase is on a horizontal ground.

premise: Normal Force (N) acts upward, perpendicular to the ground.
conclusion: N is the supporting force of the ground.

premise: Applied Force (F) acts at an angle θ above the horizontal.
conclusion: F has horizontal and vertical components.

premise: Frictional Force (f) acts opposite to the direction of motion, proportional to the normal force.
Resolve the applied force into components.
conclusion: Horizontal component: F cos θ, Vertical component: F sin θ.

premise: Equilibrium conditions in the horizontal direction.
Equilibrium conditions in the vertical direction.
Substitute N from the vertical equilibrium into the horizontal equilibrium.
Substitute N = mg - F sin θ into F cos θ = μN.
conclusion: F cos θ = μ(mg - F sin θ).
μ = F cos θ / (mg - F sin θ).

premise: Given F = 90 N, m = 15 kg, g = 10 m/s², and Fg = 150 N.
The minimum force is achieved when the angle θ maximizes the horizontal component relative to the frictional force.
